Cars of reluctant parking ticket payers may
soon be wearing bright orange "Denver
Boots," according to a Transit and Traffic
Department spokesman.
The boot is used to immobilize the cars of
persons who have three or more one-month
overdue parking tickets. Part of the boot covers
a front tire hubcap; a metal arm extends from
this cover to cross in front of the tire and attach to its inside.
"Any attempt to move the car will render
damange," said Fred Raynor, a Transit and
Traffic spokesman.
To have the boot removed, the owner of the
car has to go to the Parking Fines Division in
the Municipal Building downtown. After the
owner pays the amount due for "outstanding
penalties and citations" and an additional $24
for the booting, parking control agents from

Transit and Traffic will go out and remove the
boot.
The car will be un-booted "generally within
half an hour," Raynor said.
If the car's owner does not pay within three
days, the car will be towed. The boot fee is
dropped if the vehicle is towed, but a $27 towing charge is then added to the amount owed
for the parking tickets.
Begun on March 15, the boot has been used
on 60 or 70 cars throughout the city and has
proven "more effective than towing," Raynor
said.
The boot method is also easier and cheaper
than towing, Raynor added, and there is a
smaller chance of damage to the car.
The response from owners of booted cars
thus far has been "surprised more than anything," Raynor said.

To the Editor:

The Unintended Dangers
Of Undergraduate Emphasis
If the University would only put a greater
emphasis on undergraduates, Hopkins
would be a much better place for undergrads, right'? Not necessarily. Certainly,
more attention to the undergraduate curriculum, Financial aid and housing is warranted. A major shift in emphasis, however,
towards undergraduates at Hopkins if at the
expense of the graduate program, may have
some unintended and undesirable consequences. A shift towards undergraduates could
prove disastrous to the humanities and social
sciences at Hopkins, unless preventative steps
are taken.
Johns Hopkins is, and probably always
will be, a graduate-oriented institution.
Nevertheless, over the past ten to fifteen
years, Hopkins' emphasis has shifted somewhat towards undergraduate education.
Undergraduate enrollment has increased
dramatically; the number of graduate students has declined slightly. While graduate
students have battled to attain financial aid
awards that are competitive with peer institutions, federal policies have made it easier for
a greater number of Americans to afford a
college education at the undergraduate level.
Recent shifts in the economy and government philosophy may result in a crisis in
higher education. As funds dwindle, institutions such as Hopkins may be forced to
make difficult choices. Hopkins must decide
how to balance undergraduates with graduates, the humanities and social sciences with
the sciences. Already, the administration hass
provided indications that it will try to offset declining federal monies for undergraduate financial aid with University
money. Such a proposition is not only commendable but essential to maintain equality.
of opportunity for a college education. This
type of commitment is expensive, however,
and could conceivably be financed at the expense of any graduate aid currently dependent on University funds.
Further decreases in graduate aid have
severe implications for non-science departments at Hopkins. Many departments in the
social sciences and humanities depend on
graduate students for their strength. The
History Department, for instance, is one of
the strongest in the nation. Aside from
research, its primary function is to train
graduate students. Undergraduates, however, can reap benefits by taking courses by
premier historians. Cutting back on graduate
programs, thus, makes it more difficult for
undergraduates to receive a well-rounded,

liberal arts education. The connection between undergraduate enrollment and graduate programs is most important when it
comes to the issue of teaching positions.
Many graduate programs justify their request funds on the grounds that they need
teaching assistants to instruct undergraduates. Although the administration tries to
avoid having undergraduate enrollment dictating support for the graduate program, the
fact remains that in all likelihood, it' there
are to be any further cuts in graduate aid,
they will affect those departments that do
not use the money for teaching positions.
This puts departments such as Classics and
Near Eastern Studies in a very precarious
position because very few undergrads take
courses in these areas. Such departments,
therefore, have little need for teaching positions. Unless admissions policies change,
teaching positions for graduate students will
continue to be available in the sciences,
because most Hopkins undergraduates take
many science courses..
If' the size of the undergraduate body remains the same in the midst of tough financial times, there are, nevertheless, several
ways by which to avoid the declension of
liberal arts at Hopkins. The best but most
difficult solution would entail changing the
image of Hopkins in order to attract more
liberal arts majors. The recent acquisition of
the Peabody Conservatory and the development of academic programs in Italy and
China contribute to a shift in image. Yet as
long as Hopkins Hospital and Med School are
internationally renowned, Hopkins will continue to attract many science-oriented
undergraduates. A more feasible alternative
would entail a restructuring of the
undergraduate curriculum that would require
students to pursue .a broader liberal arts
education, thus, saving some social science
and humanities departments from death.
Of course, if the University's capital campaign is successful, there will be no reason
to worry; there will be enough money to support a strong graduate as well as undergraduate program, thus maintaining the
balance of liberal arts versus sciences at
Hopkins. Yet there is no guarantee that the
University will be able to obtain the revenue
necessary to fulfill all of its desires, and if
funds decrease, difficult choices will have to
be made. It is important to begin thinking
about these choices and to understand some
of the not so obvious implications that some
of these choices entait.

Will The Soviet Union Survive Until 1984
To the Editor:
"Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?" That is the
question a Soviet dissident
author, Andrei Amalrik, posed
in a book published in 1970,
after his involuntary servitude
in Siberian labor camps. He
predicted the end of the regime
he defied.
In 1978, as an emigre, he
qualified his prediction. He said
he was too young when he
wrote that book, the 1984 deadline was not to be taken literally, a dead tree can still stand up,
and so forth. With these reservations, he again projected his
question: "Will the Soviet
Union Still Survive Until
1984?"
In 1983, we are in the advent
of this denouement. Amalrik
had put a "hold" on the countdown on his question. Now, a
greater question supervenes: In
the context of the nuclear arms
race and mad Frankensteinian
high-tech, will the Soviet
Union, the United States and
indeed the world jointly survive
until 1984?
Optimists will say yes,

though a soothsayer may remind us that 1984 has not yet
come and gone(except the 1984
of George Orwell). But optimists can still prevail by appending to our survival question a common-sense reservation demanding a total abolishment of nuclear weaponry, not
just a reduction or "freeze." lf
we do not become abolitionists,
will we still survive until 1984?
That is the question.
Arthur J. Dzura

Charles Carrollton, the last surviving signer of the
Declaration of Independence.

August 25, 1830. .1-he horse won. The visitor then

including the massive front of a modern locomotive,
and a display of fine china that was used on trains
during the 19th century.

"Observation Car," the multimedia theater within
the museum. Among the films shown is the Chessie

of riding behind a coal-powered steam locomotive.

the train as it pulled into the many small-town stations along its route.

The horses which race at Pimlico are among the

second year. The majority of the horses which race
at Pimlico are between three and eight years old,

depending upon the time of season, their conditioning, and their age.
Pimlico itself has an illustrious history. It first
opened on October 25, 1870, and after Saratoga,
is the second-oldest race track in the United States.
It is owned and operated by the Maryland Jockey
Club, the nation's oldest sporting association.
Pimlico is the home of the National Jockeys' Hall
of Fame and the Woodlawn Vase, billed as "the
most valuable trophy in American sports." The
vase, valued at over $750,000, is the Preakness
trophy. Since 1953, a half-sized reproduction of the
vase has been awarded to the Preakness winner

every year.
It is the Preakness, of course, for which Pimlico
is best known. The Preakness is the middle jewel
of the Triple Crown, three races held every year and
regarded as the best of the racing world. The other
two classics of the Friple Crown are the Kentucky
Derby and the Belmont Stakes. These races are
reserved for the premier three-year-olds in the land,
and have hosted all the great names in thoroughbred
history: Man O'War, Secretariat, Seattle Slew, Affirmed, Spectacular Bid and more.
In recent years, the Preakness has become almost
as famous for its infield party as for its racing quality. Pimlico general manager Chick Lang contends
that "it's Woodstock, a family picnic, the Indy 500,
and a carnival all rolled into one." Infield attendance alone has grown from 12,000 in 1971 f o over

drinks. Some use wheelbarrows, wagons, or shopping carts."
Pimlico officials are not averse to the reputation
that the Preakness infield has acquired. They bill
the infield as the younger crowd's Preakness. If
some of these younger fans catch the racing bug,
Pimlico will benefit in the long run, explains Lang.
Otherwise,"we promote the idea to come out and
picnic, and have fun."
Pimlico, with its colorful 113-year tradition, has
achieved a position of admiration among racing
fans from Baltimore and beyond. From the prestige
of the Preakness to "Cockey" Johnson', from the
in ield party to the Woodlawn Vase, from that lonely 6:00 a.m. workout to the 1:00 post time, Pimlico

To the Editor:

The Unintended Dangers
Of Undergraduate Emphasis
If the University would only put a greater
emphasis on undergraduates, Hopkins
would be a much better place for undergrads, right'? Not necessarily. Certainly,
more attention to the undergraduate curriculum, Financial aid and housing is warranted. A major shift in emphasis, however,
towards undergraduates at Hopkins if at the
expense of the graduate program, may have
some unintended and undesirable consequences. A shift towards undergraduates could
prove disastrous to the humanities and social
sciences at Hopkins, unless preventative steps
are taken.
Johns Hopkins is, and probably always
will be, a graduate-oriented institution.
Nevertheless, over the past ten to fifteen
years, Hopkins' emphasis has shifted somewhat towards undergraduate education.
Undergraduate enrollment has increased
dramatically; the number of graduate students has declined slightly. While graduate
students have battled to attain financial aid
awards that are competitive with peer institutions, federal policies have made it easier for
a greater number of Americans to afford a
college education at the undergraduate level.
Recent shifts in the economy and government philosophy may result in a crisis in
higher education. As funds dwindle, institutions such as Hopkins may be forced to
make difficult choices. Hopkins must decide
how to balance undergraduates with graduates, the humanities and social sciences with
the sciences. Already, the administration hass
provided indications that it will try to offset declining federal monies for undergraduate financial aid with University
money. Such a proposition is not only commendable but essential to maintain equality.
of opportunity for a college education. This
type of commitment is expensive, however,
and could conceivably be financed at the expense of any graduate aid currently dependent on University funds.
Further decreases in graduate aid have
severe implications for non-science departments at Hopkins. Many departments in the
social sciences and humanities depend on
graduate students for their strength. The
History Department, for instance, is one of
the strongest in the nation. Aside from
research, its primary function is to train
graduate students. Undergraduates, however, can reap benefits by taking courses by
premier historians. Cutting back on graduate
programs, thus, makes it more difficult for
undergraduates to receive a well-rounded,

liberal arts education. The connection between undergraduate enrollment and graduate programs is most important when it
comes to the issue of teaching positions.
Many graduate programs justify their request funds on the grounds that they need
teaching assistants to instruct undergraduates. Although the administration tries to
avoid having undergraduate enrollment dictating support for the graduate program, the
fact remains that in all likelihood, it' there
are to be any further cuts in graduate aid,
they will affect those departments that do
not use the money for teaching positions.
This puts departments such as Classics and
Near Eastern Studies in a very precarious
position because very few undergrads take
courses in these areas. Such departments,
therefore, have little need for teaching positions. Unless admissions policies change,
teaching positions for graduate students will
continue to be available in the sciences,
because most Hopkins undergraduates take
many science courses..
If' the size of the undergraduate body remains the same in the midst of tough financial times, there are, nevertheless, several
ways by which to avoid the declension of
liberal arts at Hopkins. The best but most
difficult solution would entail changing the
image of Hopkins in order to attract more
liberal arts majors. The recent acquisition of
the Peabody Conservatory and the development of academic programs in Italy and
China contribute to a shift in image. Yet as
long as Hopkins Hospital and Med School are
internationally renowned, Hopkins will continue to attract many science-oriented
undergraduates. A more feasible alternative
would entail a restructuring of the
undergraduate curriculum that would require
students to pursue .a broader liberal arts
education, thus, saving some social science
and humanities departments from death.
Of course, if the University's capital campaign is successful, there will be no reason
to worry; there will be enough money to support a strong graduate as well as undergraduate program, thus maintaining the
balance of liberal arts versus sciences at
Hopkins. Yet there is no guarantee that the
University will be able to obtain the revenue
necessary to fulfill all of its desires, and if
funds decrease, difficult choices will have to
be made. It is important to begin thinking
about these choices and to understand some
of the not so obvious implications that some
of these choices entait.

The B&O Railroad Museum, located about 1 mile

that was erected 1883-1884. The museum and
grounds underwent a $2 million renovation during
the early 1970s, in preparation for the sesquicentennial celebration of the B&O Railroad's founding in
1827. The museum is expected to attract over
100,000 visitors this year.
Located all around the exterior of the museum
are dozens of locomotives and cars, each a significant milestone in man's progress on the rails.

the museum is the B&O Railroad's "First Stone:.

including the massive front of a modern locomotive,
and a display of fine china that was used on trains
during the 19th century.
